critique: The document is an executive order related to the Renegotiation Act of 1951. It designates three agencies (Defense Materials Procurement Agency, Bureau of Mines, and Geological Survey) as included within the definition of "Department" for the purposes of Title I of the Act. It also makes the provisions of Title I applicable to all contracts with these agencies and related subcontracts, to the extent of the amounts received or accrued on or after October 1, 1951. The tone is formal and legalistic. The language is precise and technical. The context is national defense. As president, the primary emotions I want to elicit are a sense of confidence and assurance that the government is taking necessary steps to strengthen national defense. There is no explicit mention of emotions. The actions are related to contracts and subcontracts, so the emotions are likely to be muted. Joy: 1, Sadness: 1, Anger: 1, Fear: 1, Disgust: 1, Surprise: 1. Critique: The initial scores are all 1 because the document is very formal and does not explicitly try to elicit any emotions. However, the document is related to national defense, so it is possible that the president wants to elicit a sense of confidence and assurance. Therefore, I will increase the scores for joy and surprise slightly. Revised scores: Joy: 2, Sadness: 1, Anger: 1, Fear: 1, Disgust: 1, Surprise: 2.
